div.p:
I attended Public worship this morning at the Hall of the House of Representatives where the services were performed by a stranger neither of the Chaplains of the two Houses of Congress being present. His text was from Hebrew 11.26. “Esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt” omitting the remainder of that verse “for he had respect unto the recompense of the reward”— The discourse was calm and temparate without declamation or enthusiasm—consisting chiefly of philosophical remarks upon the nature and operation of reproach upon the temper and the minds of men— With an application of it as a trial of the character of Moses— He did
not, however, explain by what authority the Apostle, represents Moses, as having been subjected to the reproach of Christ fifteen hundred years before Christ appeared upon earth, it must have been altogether in a figurative sense— Paul is expatiating upon the power and efficacy of Faith as the foundation of Religious principle—the Faith of Moses was in the promises, of Jehovah from whom he is stated to have received direct and personal revelations. there is however nothing which indicates, that the future existance of Christ, was ever revealed to him— It is somewhat extraordinary that in this passage of the Epistle to the Hebrews the name of Christ, should have been introduced at all— Returning home from the Capitol I met, coming and from the door of my own house Mr. Robert C. Winthrop and Mr. Harrison Ritchie of Boston Grandson of Mr. Harrison Gray Otis who returned, and made a visit of a few minutes to me— After dinner at Saint John’s Church, Mr. Doudnay read the evening service for the fourth Sunday after the Epiphany and preached from St Luke 15.10. “Likewise I say unto you there is joy in the presence of the Angels of God over one sinner, that repenteth.” This Discourse was not upon the duty or the efficacy of repentance but it was an Essay to maintain the assertion that there are Angels in the presence of God, and that they take interest in the Characters and fortunes of mankind. The text is indeed conclusive of the existance of such spiritual Beings and leads to the inference not however so certain of the doctrine of Guardian Angels. One of the most pleasing opinions that can be entertained in the Faith of Christianity— There are other passages especially in the Book of Daniel perhaps, more strongly supporting this Doctrine— Which however I do not consider as positively revealed— Mr. Doudnay is a sober and sensible but not an eloquent Preacher— Archibald Campbell and Isaac Hull Adams were here and spent an hour this evening—

The weather on Saturday last was almost at Summer heat— I went to dinner with Gov Seward without a great coat— Yesterday was severely cold and I found myself on rising with hoarseness, sore throat, and with threatned Catarrhal cough

This morning Mr. Thomas H. Perry a Professor in the navy of the United called on me. He had visited me twice in the course of the last Summer and Autumn at Quincy, he is anxious with regard to his station in the Navy Mr. Bancroft the Secretary of that Department having in his late Report to the President proposed to abolish that corps of Officers. He appears to apprehend also some personal aversion or prejudice of the Secretary against himself— I assured him that if he wished a representation should be made in his behalf I should cheerfully render him any service in my power— He had no particular request to make but stated that he might call on my good offices on certain contingencies and if such should occur he would do so— At the House, three new resolutions relating to the Oregon Territory Controversy were introduced the first by Edmund S. Darjin of Alabama, the second by John W. Tibbatts of Kentucky and the third, by John Pettit of Indiana. Objections were made to the reception of them all and they were all received by suspension of the rules and referred to Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Robert C. Winthrop presented a Memorial from Martha Gray widow of Capt Robert Gray the discoverer of the Columbia river in the North-West coast of America praying for Pension, on the ground that her deceased husband was in the service of this Country during the War of the Revolution and that she has been debarred from a pension as his widow only because her marriage took place in Feb. 1794. the limitation commencing with the 1. of January of that year. The Memorial was referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions and ordered to be printed. A 4th. resolution relating to the Oregon Controversy was offered by William J. Brown of Virginia, and referred with the rest to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and ordered to be printed. Mr. Thomas. H. Bayly of Accomac was permitted to make an other personal explanation in reply to the Speech of Andrew Johnson of Tenn made last Saturday Johnson replied again this day and Bayly rejoined and Johnson surrejoined and Bayly had the last words— Much of the controversy between these two gentlemen related to me, Bayly having taunted the Democratic supporters of the Notice to be given to Great Britain by the charge that they were taking
me for their Leader and saying it was a lead which he was not disposed to follow— Upon this remark, Johnson’s answer on Saturday was very severe and this day still more Cutting. Bayly after manifesting several times great excitement at the remarks of Johnson finally left his Seat and went out of the House. By a singular coincidence two citizens of North Carolina named Jones and Johnson fought a Duel this morning at Bladensburg in which Johnson was killed and a rumor was circulated throughout this City this day that this Duel was between Bayly and Johnson in which my champion of Tennessee had fallen—fortunately I heard nothing of this rumor till it was ascertained to be unfounded;—the only Duel between these Parties this day having been as on Saturday merely a strife of words— Mr. Francis. B. Stockton and his wife were here this evening. Mrs. John Adams, her daughter with Walter Hellen, passed the night till two in the morning at the third Washington City Assembly.

div.p:
I finished reading, this morning, the Mystères de Paris, the last, volume, being in the English translated, which I had taken, out, from the Library of Congress, and this Day, returned— It is, a dismal, and melancholy tale, painting in glowing colours, the vices, crimes, and wretchedness, of the City, of Paris, It is, a subject, of interesting comparison, with, the “Paysan perverti” of Retif de La Bretonne, published, shortly before, the French Revolution, and with, the Tableaux De Paris, by Mercier, published, in the midst, of the American Revolutionary War— Mrs. John Adams, was quite sick, all this Day, and kept, her chamber. Mrs. Smith, still remains, confined, to hers. At the House James, A. Black of South Carolina, offered, a Joint Resolution, with a long preamble, authorizing, the President, to give notice, to the British Government, of the annulment, of the Convention, of 1827. with a proviso, for further negotiations, and George. C. Dromgoole, of Virginia, introduced, a Bill, for effecting, the same purpose, with an appropriation, of money, the amount, left in Blank, and further negotiation, recommended. The object, of multiplying these projects of Legislation, I suppose, to be intended, for the purpose, of defeating them all which I have little doubt, is the systematic proceeding, of the Polk Adminis
tration. I hinted, as much, in anticipation, in my speech, of the 2. January and this day, Thomassin of Kentucky said to me laughing that in addition to all my other properties I should prove in this case a Prophet. George Ashman, of Springfield, Sixth Congressional District of Massachusetts moved a call on the President, of inquiry as to the proceedings of the Army of the United States towards Mexico and also the movements of the Navy it was laid over one day for consideration— The Oregon Debate was resumed in Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, and Shelton. F. Leake, of Virginia, made a warm, hour speech, against giving the Notice, with no little excitement, under the imputations against the Virginia, and her Delegation, on the floor, for deserting, the Administration, upon, this Oregon Question. The next Speaker, was, Stephen Strong, of Owego, New-York, in favor of the Notice, rather, dull, and heavy, and next came William Sawyer of the 5th. Congressional District, of Ohio with the wildest and most original speech yet delivered on the Question. He considered the Oregon region as a gift of Heaven to the North American Union for propagating the principles of Liberty, and good Government. This he thought was equivalent to the manifest destiny of Mr. Baker of Illinois and he lead with a sledge hammer. The doctrines of the new Anglo-Virginia School especially of Pendleton and Beddinger one of whom has asserted that Great Britain had never committed an outrage or done a wrong without atoning and apologising for it— This he denied and said it was a question of veracity between him and the gentleman from Virginia who thereupon started up and repeated in a highly excited tone, the words, a Question of veracity, upon which Sawyer looking at him with a smile said I mean nothing personal— He was very bitter in replying to the assertion that Great Britain had done us no wrong without atoning and apologising he said it, he said he owed her an old grudge as his Father had before him, and specified a number of wrongs from the first settlement of this Country down to the present day which she had committed and never had apologised or atoned for and never would, at this very day he said Great Britain was paying the Indian Tribes within our Borders hundreds of thousands of
dollars, a year, to purchase, their hostility against us, for which we were obliged, to pay, the same Indians, one million; and three quarters, every year, to purchase back their friendship.— Joshua. F. Bell of Ky next, took the floor, and at his motion the Committee rose— Jacob Collamer of Vermont, offered, a resolution, calling, on the President, for copies of any correspondence, between, this Government, and that, of Great Britain in relation to the Country west of the Rocky Mountains which may have occurred, since the last Annual Message of the President objection was made to the reception of this Resolution, but on motion of Collamer the Rules, were suspended. Houston of Alabama made a motion to lay the Resolution on the Table, which was refused by yeas and nays 62 to 94, Isaac. E. Holmes of South Carolina asked leave to present a Memorial of a Southern Convention, held at Memphis, in Tennessee to deliberate on measures calculated to promote the interests of the Western Country over this Convention John. C. Calhoun presided and the Memorial was in substance an application to Congress for appropriations of internal improvement, Holmes said, that all he wished was, to present the Memorial, and have it referred, to the Committee on Commerce and printed but objection was made to its reception. Holmes moved to suspend the rules and called for the yeas and nays, but the House adjourned without taking them or deciding the Question. Evening visits from Gov Seward with a gentleman from Albany by the name of Stevens, and also from Mr. Mosely— Mr. Seward is to leave the City to return home to-morrow morning— Mr. Mosely just convalescent from a long and severe illness declines his invitation to my wife’s Ball next Thursday evening—

4. VI— Preparations for the Party to-morrow evening— We dined in my Library and cabinet— In the House the Question upon the Memorial from the Memphis Convention, offered yesterday by Isaac E. Holmes of South Carolina was taken by yeas and nays this morning on the motion to suspend the Rules, which was refused by a vote of 72. to 78. so that the Memorial was not received. I did not reach the House untill the call had passed by my name and was therefore by the rules not permitted to vote on the Question Tibbatts moved a Resolution for closing the Debate on the Oregon Notice Resolutions on Monday next at 1/2 past 2. and moved
a Call of the House— Ashman moved, to lay the Resolution on the Table Winthrop objected that the Resolution was not in order because it was identical with a Resolution offered yesterday and then laid on the Table. The Speaker erroneously sustained this objection for the Rule is not that a Motion identical with one laid in the Table cannot be renewed on the next day, it applies only to a Resolution rejected but the decision of the Speaker was, not Question and the objection was avoided by merely changing the hour of the proposed closure of the Debate from 1/2 past 2. to 2. o’clock— Ashman withdrew the motion to lay it on Table but it was renewed, by Roberts of Mississippi and after some caviling between Yost and McConnell the Resolution was laid on the Table by yeas and nays 93 to 91. McKay Chairman of the Committee Ways and Means reported 2 Appropriation Bills one of which was to enable the President to receive a cession of certain property from the state of Texas. Committee of the Whole, on the state of the Union, Tibbatts in the Chair— Joshua F. Bell of Kentucky made an hour speech followed by Lucien B. Chase of Clarksville of Tenn Seaborn Jones of Columbus Georgia and Barcly Martin of Columbia of Tennessee all in favor of giving the notice. Martin made a very pointed referrence partly complimentary and partly censorious upon me— At the motion of McKay the Committee passed from the notice Resolution to the Bill to enable the President to receive a cession of Property from the State of Texas. He proposed an appropriation of $3,000. as compensation to a Commissioner for receiving the property and the scattering fire of Debate arose upon the necessity of any such Commissioner This was a mere consumption of time till the previous Question was made and seconded the Bill being reported to the House it was passed and the House adjourned—

Mr. Healy called upon me this morning . . . observing that Inman one of the Painters employed under the authority of Congress to paint one of the large pictures to be suspended in the Rotunda of the Capitol had recently died, that he believed he had not even commenced upon the painting though he had received a large part of the sum
which was to have been paid for the work. He said that he was very desirous of obtaining the engagement to supply that picture a subject of deep interest to him as of great importance to his reputation— I promised to do all in my power, to obtain this employment for him. He observed that it might be objected that his talent had been hitherto tested only in the painting of Portraits, but he thought it might be answered that at the time of Inman’s appointment he had never been distinguished except as a portrait Painter, which is true— He made some comparison of opinions upon the comparative merits of the two Pictures already suspended in the Rotunda by Chapman and Weir— We agreed that this last was a work of real merit— The baptism of princess Pocahuntas did not meet as much of his approbation as of mine— Mr. Healy asked my advice also for the choice of a subject in the event of his obtaining the employment for the work. I mentioned several to him and among the rest the first Congress of the Colonies held at New York in 1765. He thought well of this, but it is subject to many objections and only fit for future consideration— At the House Sterling Price moved a Resolution to close the debate on the Oregon Notice resolution next Monday at 3. o’clock P.M. and moved the Previous Question McKay moved a Call of the House which after some difficulty was carried— After some progress further proceedings in the Hall were dispensed with and Caleb. B. Smith of Indiana moved to lay the Resolution on the Table; refused by yeas and nays, 86. to 107. the Previous Question was then carried and the Resolution by yeas and nays 109 to 87. I now voted against laying on the Table and for the Resolution— McKay moved that until next Tuesday the House should meet at 10. o’clock in the morning which was carried. F. A. Cunningham of Eton. Ohio asked to introduce a new resolution for giving the Oregon notice his objection was made to its reception and a motion of McDowell to suspend the Rules to receive it—which failed— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Tibbatts in the Chair on the Oregon notice Resolutions— Meredith P. Gentry of Tennessee made a very vehement hour speech against giving the notice which he thought would infalibly lead to War and said he believed that negotiations between the two Governments had been renewed on this subject and insisted on the right of the House concerning it— He appealed to Charles. J. Ingersoll, Chair
man of the Committee of Foreign Affairs, who answered that he believed negotiation had been resumed and that a Communication from the Executive would be made to the House at an early day— Gentry was followed by Edmund S. Dargin of Alabama and Columbus Delano both in favor of the notice. Robert B. Rhett of South Carolina took the floor, but there was no quorum in the House and after a considerable struggle the Committee rose and at 4. o’clock 40. minutes the House adjourned— We had this evening at our house a large Party. A Bridal Party given because our grandaughter, Mary Louisa was one of the Bridemaids at the Marriage of General Jesup’s daughter Mary to James L. Blair, a past Midshipman in the Navy of the United States— The company consisting of about three hundred persons, was of course composed of persons of all political Parties. It passed off pleasantly. The dancing having been continued before and after supper till between 1. and 2 o’clock in the Morning— Our neighbour Mr. Parris gave us for the occasion the use of the front lower room of his house. In yielding this tribute, of sacrifice to the benevolent courtesies of social life, I rejoice that it has been accomplished without any sinister accident—

This was the day upon which there should have been, a meeting of the Select Committee on the Smithsonian Bequest, It had been so notified to me, yesterday morning, by Mr. Owen, the Chairman, but after the Resolution of the House, to meet till next Tuesday, at 10. o’clock in the morning; he came to me, and we agreed to postpone, the meeting of the Committee, till after next Monday.— The House accordingly met this morning at 10. It was already in Session, when I reached the Hall. The Quorum had not been formed precisely at ten, and motions to dispense with the reading of the Journal, to go into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, without a Quorum, and to adjourn, had been successively made— The Journal of yesterday was read. A Quorum had come in and went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Tibbatts in the Chair, and Robert B. Rhett, who had the floor from yesterday, declined to exercise the right, and I found Jefferson
Davis of Missouri, addressing the Committee, against giving the notice— George S. Houston of Tennessee, Charles W. Cathgart of Indiana and John P. Martin of Kentucky followed in succession all in favour of giving the notice but expressing different opinions with regard to the extent of our title to be insisted upon with our Controversy with England. Mr. Martin, referred, to the opinion which I had expressed that the Notice would not lead to War because one or the other of the Parties would yield of their pretensions till it should come to an agreement of compromise had misunderstood me, and I repeated what I had said that if our Government should persist in our Claims to the whole of Oregon Great Britain would ultimately yield, but if they should not and Great Britain should refuse to yield our own Government would and I had more apprehension that the President would back out and yield too much than that the notice would yield to War— Isaac Parish of Ohio offered four long Joint Resolutions full of bavad? against any balance of power in this American Union or any permission to European Monarchs of interfering in the Territorial rights of this Nation of any compromise of the right of this Country to the whole Territory of Oregon but he made no speech in support of his Resolutions— Henry. S. Clarke of North Carolina moved the Committee to rise, which was refused and he made his hour speech in favour of the Notice, because he had considered the Annexation of Texas and the occupation of Oregon to be kindred objects parts of one system and having himself supported the annexation of Texas, he should vote, for the occupation of Oregon, for consistency sake. If in negotiation our Government should accept of the parallel of 49. he would not raise an insurrection against it, and if we should insist upon the whole of Oregon he thought it would lead to War— Solomon Foot of Vermont repeated the motion for the Committee to rise— On taking the Question there was no quorum—upon which the Committee rose and the Chairman reported the fact to the House— Dromgoole moved a Call of the House A motion to adjourn succeeded, rejected by yeas and nays 47. to 74. a quorum voting. Droomgoole withdrew the motion for a Call. Tibbatts resumed the Chair of the Committee of the whole and Foot made his hour speech, animated and eloquent against the notice and descriptive of the horrors of War— D. A Starkweather of Ohio made a backwoodman’s speech sharp as a
needle, and blunt as a Mall in support of the notice, and specially defencive of the people of the West, against some reflections which had been cast upon them, by others— Washington Hunt of New-York, made an hour speech in support of the notice after which Truman Smith of Connecticut took in the floor— Motion was made that the Committee rise—upon which the vote was 41. to 48. no quorum which was again reported to the House and after another Motion to adjourn and another Motion for a Call of the House had failed, a final Motion for adjournment at 20 min. past 8. o’clock was carried 41. to 41. by the casting vote of the Speaker—

We received this morning, a Letter of a few lines, from our Son at Boston, with the most distressing intelligence, that his son, Arthur had the croup with such severity, that there was on Thursday the date of the Letter, little, if any hope left, of his surviving it— Another Letter from Elizabeth C. Adams gave the particulars of his illness, which commenced, with a heavy cold, on Monday, the second day, of this month— Upon this dispensation of Divine Providence—our only consolation is in the mercy of God, and our only duty, humble resignation, to his will— At the House, which was to meet at 10. o’clock this morning the Speaker was belated a few minutes later by a fall of snow; Immediately upon being called to order they went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Tibbatts in the Chair, on the Oregon Notice— Truman Smith of Connecticut reporter of the minority Report from the Committee on Foreign Affairs made an hour speech quite vehement against giving the notice. Denied the validity of our title beyond the Valley, drained by the waters, of the Columbia river, and was willing to give to Great Britain, the line of Frazer’s river. Alexander. D. Simms of South Carolina followed in favor of the Notice and for accepting the line of Latitude 49. Then came, Archibald Atkinson, of Virginia, in support of the Notice, ready to maintain the title to 54.40. and was in favor, of the Bill offered by his colleague Dromgoole, yesterday— George Fries, of Ohio, spoke in support of the notice, objected to throwing any responsibility upon the President, and though
avowing himself averse to War, predicted in the event, that it should come the voluntary annexation of Canada to this Union. Armistead Burt of South Carolina, Garrett Davis of Kentucky, Robert Smith of Illinois Joseph A. Woodward of South Carolina, Henry. D. Foster of Pennsylvania Archibald. Yell of Arkansas, Augustus. C. Dodge delegate from the Territory of Iowa and David Wilmot of Pennsylvania followed hour by hour in the Debate till midnight— I left the House about 20 minutes past eleven just after Mr. Wilmot had commenced his speech— At twelve the House adjourned— Thomas. B. King of Georgia having the floor for Monday morning— At 3. o’clock in the afternoon at the invitation of Mr. Grinnell and Mr. Winthrop I went and dined with them at their lodgings at Mrs. Whitwells. I came home and about midnight with a heavy heart retired to bed—

A Letter from Elizabeth. C. Adams, dated, on Friday at two o’clock in the afternoon, informed us, that the Dear child Arthur, was yet living, but without more cheering hope of his recovery— I attended Public Worship, in the Hall of the House of Representatives, where a prayer was made by a stranger, and the Chaplain of the House Mr. Milburne preached a short Discourse, from Isaiah 9. and a part of the 6th. verse, “And his name shall be called Wonderful”— Mr. Milburne, made very little of his text, which connected with the remainder of the verse and that immediately succeeding it, is the most explicit and truly wonderful prophesy of the Saviour Jesus Christ, contained in the Scriptures of the Old Testament.— A popular Discourse of an hour, as much as any auditory will at this day tolerate for a Sermon, is altogether inadequate fully to expound this passage of the Book of Isaiah. Neither did Mr. Milburn attempt it nor do I suppose, him, competent to perform it. I think he should not have taken a fragment of that verse for a sermon in that Hall— In the afternoon, at Saint John’s Church, Mr. Pyne read the evening service for Septuagesima Sunday and preached from Proverbs 3.17. “Her ways are ways of pleasantness and all her paths are peace.”— He observed that this verse, was part of a beautiful description, of wisdom
which in the language of Solomon the Author of the Book of Proverbs was understood to mean, the principle of Religion, or a perpetual obedience to the Will of God— The Discourse, was like all Mr. Pyne’s Sermons, ingenious and interesting, though not peculiarly impressive— He retained the children after the Service, to catechize them— Miss Cutts was here this afternoon after evening service—and we had no other visiters—

We received another Letter, from Elizabeth. C. Adams, dated on Saturday, and advising us, that the child, still lived, but without a cheering glimpse of hope— At 10. o’clock this morning, I attended at the House, which I found in Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union— Tibbatts, in the Chair, and Thomas. B. King of Georgia, speaking, against the Resolution for giving the Oregon Notice— I had scarcely taken my seat, when he addressed himself personally to me, with a charge of inconsistency, for having in years 1818. and 1827. agreed, to the temporary Conventions, with Great Britain, concerning the Oregon region and now declaring myself ready, to put an end to that compact. He turned his face from the Speaker towards me and asked the question Why, this change had come over my mind? I had been for several days, urged, by sundry members of the House to address the Committee, on this subject, but the wretched state of my health, and the burden of affliction, bearing me down, at this moment, had so totally discouraged me that I entered, the House, with a determination to wait for the decision, and give to it only my affirmative vote— This direct call from Mr. King however I could not resist— I rose and said, that without admitting the right of the gentleman from Georgia, to put a direct and personal question to me in that House, I was however ready to answer him— His question was “Whether the title of the United States to the whole of Oregon to Latitude 54.–40. was clear and indisputable? This question I said was susceptible of two different constructions—one with referrence to right and wrong, and another with referrence to fact—that as to the question of right—I
did hold the Title of the United States to be, clear, and indisputable, but as to the Fact, if every thing is disputable which is disputed I could not say, that the title was indisputable, and if every thing disputed by Great Britain was disputable, I thought it would be difficult any indisputable title, without a change in the definition of words— Mr. King replied that my answer was just such as he had expected, but that as I held these opinions he marvelled why I had not formally protested against any claim of title, by Great Britain to Oregon in 1818. and 1827. Without rejoining immediately I suffered Mr. King to finish his speech and then rose—and made myself a fragment of a speech which was arrested, before I had half done, by the expiration of the hour— I took some notice of the disorderly manner in which Mr. King, had thought proper to address himself to me, in the course of the Debate, whereupon, he explained that he had intended nothing disrespectful, which I have no doubt was true or disorderly which it certainly was— I then, entered upon the consideration, of the title—and requested the Speaker to hand over to the Clerk the small Book which he occasionally used for administering to the Members of the House their solemn oaths, to support the Constitution of the United States— He passed the little Bible over to the Clerk B. B. French who at my request read the 26, 27. & 28th. verses of the first chapter of Genesis—which I said in my judgment contained the foundation of all Human Territorial rights—whether of eminent domain—National Jurisdiction or Individual Property from the right of the United States to the soil upon which the Capitol to the seat in the Chair, occupied by the Speaker of the House— This was the general title of the whole Human race to the whole of this Globe of earth, from this all other Human titles, must be derived— I then requested the Clerk to read the 8. verse of 2. Psalm—which he did—“Ask of me, and I shall give thee, the Heathen for thy inheritance and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession”—and the preceeding verses declare that the speaker of this promise was God Almighty, and the person to whom the promise was made was Jesus Christ— Then without calling on the Clerk to read, I referred to the 18. and 19. & 20th. verses of Matthew, in which after his ressurrection from the dead—Jesus Christ, spoke to his eleven disciples his last words saying—“All power is given unto me, in
Heaven and in Earth, go ye therefore, and teach all Nations baptising them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, teaching them to observe all things, whatsoever I had commanded you, and lo; I am with you, always even unto the end of the World. Amen” I proceeded to say that at the time of the discovery of this Hemisphere, by Christopher Columbus it was an Article of creed of all christian Nations, that the Bishop of Rome, as the successor of Saint Peter was the Vicar of Jesus Christ, upon earth and the Administrator of all that power, with which he had declared himself to be invested in Heaven and on Earth at the time of His ressurrection and that then, and for several preceeding Centuries, it had been a part of the Religious creed of Christendom, that the right of disposing not only of uninhabited Countries and of Countries only inhabited by Savages, but even of all earthly Kingdoms, was vested in the Pope of Rome as the Vicar and representative, of Jesus Christ, upon earth and hence it was by this assumed and recognised authority that in 1493. the spring after the discovery of Columbus, Pope Alexander 6th. gave this whole Hemisphere to Ferdinand and Isabella, King and Queen of Castille, Leon, and Aragon— I then proceeded to deduce Historically, our title, to the North West coast from Latitude 42 to 54–40. till I was arrested by the expiration of the hour— Haralson of Georgia immediately took the floor, Charles J. Ingersoll moved to suspend the hour rule to give me the opportunity to conclude— But this led to a Debate which terminated without suspending the rule— Haralson made his speech, Charles. J. Ingersoll, followed, for an hour, and Cornelius Darragh of Pennsylvania, consumed the remaining twenty minutes till three oclock the hour, at which it had been agreed that the Debate should close— The voting then commenced, and numerous Amendments were proposed, and voted upon, without Debate. The original resolution was amended and a second resolution added to it, recommending further negotiation, and was reported, to the House, where, the final vote, was taken, by yeas and nays 163 to 54. It was read a third time and passed— A motion to reconsider with the Previous Question was rejected and at six o’clock in the evening the House adjourned— I returned home, gratified with the result, but deeply dispirited, and disconsolate—

The child Arthur, has suffered a long agony. We had again a Letter, from Elizabeth. C. Adams, stating that on Sunday, he still breathed but with the prospect, that every hour, would be his last.— Our suffering, is little less protracted, and finds no comfort, but in resignation. Mr. Hoyt was here this morning, with a friend of his from Philadelphia named Hopkins— Mr. Hoyt left with me a minute of several Claims at the Pension Office, which I took there and left with Mr. Edwards the Commissioner requesting him to examine them and report to me his decision, upon them—which he promised— Mr. Brainard came and requested me to sit for a Daguerreotype likeness at Plumbes Gallery Concert Hall in the Pennsylvania Avenue where I promised to go at eleven o’clock tomorrow morning— At the House Robert McClelland, of Michigan presented resolutions of the Legislature of that State declaring the right of the United States to the Oregon Territory, to Latitude 54–40— Laid on the Table and ordered to be printed— A Message was received from the President, in answer to a Call of the 19th. December last, for copies of correspondence between this Government and Great Britain within the last two years, in relation to the Ashburton Treaty, free navigation of the river St John’s and the disputed Territory fund, with copies of Documents from the Department of State. Referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— Reports were also received from the Secretary of the Treasury, with returns of importations and Impost Duties and from Secretary of War, with returns of Militia— The Committees were called for Reports, many of which were made—chiefly upon Private Claims, favourable and adverse. John H. McHenry of Kentucky reported from the Committee on the District of Columbia, a Bill to enlarge the powers of the several Orphans Courts of the District— It related to the distribution of Property. Joshua R. Giddings of Ohio moved an Amendment, of an additional Section declaring, that Slaves shall no longer be deemed in Law to be property—within the District of Columbia and was supporting, his Amendment by beginning an Argument, when McHenry objected to the Amendment, as not in order for irrelevancy— The Speaker a pro-slavery representative from the free state of Indiana buckled close to the Slave mongers, decided, that the Amendment was irrelevant, and therefore, not in Order— Giddings appealed from this decision—and began an Argument in support of his Appeal— William. M. Treadway of
Virginia, inquired if the appeal was debatable. The Speaker answered that it was— Richard Brodhead, from Easton, Pennsylvania moved to lay the Appeal on the Table—which was carried— This decision undoubtedly wrong, serves but to show the transcendent power here exercised, over the House, by the Slave Representation, of the South— The bill was passed— George Rathbun, reported from the Committee on the Judiciary, a Resolution, calling on the Secretaries of War and the Navy, to report whether any of the Officers, Military or Naval, were employed as Clerks in the Department or otherwise and receiving double compensations and the Amount of such payments if made— He reported also a resolution, declaring that no alteration in the naturalization laws is necessary, for the preservation of the rights, interests, and morals of the People; or for guarding the Ballot Box, against every improper influence— This resolution, directed point blank, against the resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, which had been referred, to the Judiciary Committee and was itself referred, to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Rathbun moved that five thousand extra copies of the Report should be printed which was laid over for a day— Lynn Boyd, from the Committee on the Territories moved to be discharged from the consideration of a large number of the Memorials, and Remonstrances, against the annexation of Texas, and that they be laid on the Table—which was done— Robert Smith, of Illinois, from the Committee on Roads and Canals, reported, a Bill for completing the Cumberland road through Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois, and to Jefferson City, Missouri— Referred, to the Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union— Morgan L. Martin, delegate from the Wisconsin Territory, presented, a paper, signed by himself, and Augustus C. Dodge, Delegate from the Territory of Iowa, requesting leave to record on the Journals of the House, their suffrage, in favor of the Resolution of notice, adopted yesterday, by the House, which was agreed to— A Message was received from the President, with the Annual returns from the Mints. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Richard Brodhead in the Chair, on the Appropriation Bill, for Fortifications, amounting to one million of dollars, which after some small Debate, was laid aside, to be reported to the House. The Bill of Appropriations for Pensions, was taken up next— This gave rise
to a long Debate, upon an Amendment, proposed by Tibbatts, of Ky without deciding which, the Committee rose, and reported the Fortification Bill, which was passed, and the House at half past three o’clock adjourned— Mr. Hoyt was here in the evening, to inquire if I had received answers from the Commissioner of Pensions, in the cases, which I had submitted to him from Mr. Hoyt’s minutes— I had not. Mr. Hoyt is to leave the City tomorrow.

We received this morning a Letter from Elizabeth. C. Adams dated on Monday morning that the Child had not yet breathed his last. It mercifully prepared us, for the event, no longer doubtful— In the heaviness of my heart, I attended the meeting of the House; now again fixed at twelve o’clock, where, Charles. H. Carroll of New York, appeared and took his seat— Thomas. B. King asked leave to make a personal explination, of his reasons, for not voting, on the Resolution, for giving the Oregon Notice last Monday— Having obtained leave, he began in substance, an Argument against the Notice, whereupon George Rathbun rose and objected to his proceeding. He said that he was very desirous, to give his reasons, why he did vote upon that Resolution; and if the gentleman from Georgia, was permitted to make an Argument; against the measure, under colour of a personal explination, he thought he was himself, equally entitled, to deliver a counter Argument of his reasons, for voting— A straggling Debate ensued, ending in a permission, to Thomas. B. King by yeas and nays 86 to 63. to proceed in his explanation— The substance of what he said was that the reason for his declining to vote had been that the President had not communicated, the whole of the late correspondence; with the British Government, called for by the Resolution of the House, last week— He believed, that an important portion, of that correspondence, had been suppressed— Hereupon Rathbun objected again to his proceeding and after some farther chicanery he was again allowed to proceed, and finished his explination, which gave no substantial reason for flinching from his vote— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Richard Brodhead in the Chair, on the Pension Appropriation Bills— The Chairman had yesterday decided that an Amendment moved by Tibbatts enlarging the extent of the Widows Pensions, to be out of order, from which Tibbatts had taken an Appeal. He now modified his Amendment, with an additional Section to
reduce the time of Service, giving title to Pensions to three months. The Chairman decided the whole to be out of order, from which Tibbatts appealed, a long Debate followed and Brodhead’s decision was sustained by Tellers 103 to 38— Caleb B. Smith, of Indiana, moved an addition to the Bill, making arrearages of Pension, recoverable by Executors and Administrators. but Black of South Carolina moved the Committee to rise, and the House soon after adjourned—

A Letter from my Son, gave us this morning, the tidings, of the fatal issue to the desease of his youngest Son, Arthur—who died on Monday the 9th. of February at 1/2 past six o’clock, in the evening. He has passed away, like a delightful vision, and leaves a memory of blighted hopes, and blasted prospects, for which there is no consolation, to his bereaved parents, or to me, but in that resignation, for which I supplicate our Father in Heaven for them, for my partner in Life and for myself— Mr. Healey was here again this morning, and spoke of his desire, to be employed to paint the Picture, intended to supply a panel in the Rotunda of the Capitol, which has failed by the death of Mr. Inman— He said he had since he last spoke to me on this subject, reflected much, upon the selection of a subject, and the more he had thought of it, the more confirmed he had found himself in the opinion that the Congress at New-York, of 1765, was the best that could be chosen— I renewed my promise to do what I could, to obtain this work for him—but shortly afterwards, on attending at the House of Representatives, I found that this purpose also, was destined to be disappointed— Alexander H. Stephens offered a Resolution, calling on the Clerk of the House, for the reasons of the delay in delivering the remaining Copies, of Capt Fremont’s Report. George Rathbun of New-York, presented Resolutions of the Legislature of that State, against any increase in the rates of Postage— Among the Resolutions presented was one by Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana, from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, calling on the President, for Documents, relating to the payment, of the fourth and fifth instalments of the Mexican indemnity—which have been paid but not received.— Garrett Davis of Kentucky, from the same Committee made an adverse Report, on the Petition of Alexander. H. Everrett for extra allowances, upon his accounts, in
his Mission to Spain. Thomas. J. Henry of Indiana, from the Committee on Patents, reported a Bill, to enlarge the Powers, of the Chief Clerk of the Patent Office, which was passed— William. W. Campbell, of New York, from the Joint Committee on the Library, reported a Resolution instructing that Committee, to inquire into the present condition, of the Painting, ordered to be painted, by the late Henry Inman, and if found unfinished, authorising and requiring the Committee, to have it finished, at an expense, not exceeding the original appropriation— Campbell moved for the immediate passage of the Resolution, but Charles J. Ingersoll, moved its referrence to the Committee of the whole— A Debate arose, in which, I suggested, the expediency, of referring to the Committee the inquiry, whether another Artist, should be employed, instead, of procuring a Picture, commenced by one Artist and finished by another, which I believed, would necessarily result in a signal failure— After considerable discussion the whole subject, was at the motion of Robert C. Winthrop, referred back to the Joint Committee on the Library— The Pension Appropriation Bill, was then resumed for consideration, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Richard Brodhead in the Chair, which was debated, tediously, until Tibbatts offered, an additional Section, providing that no Widow whose husband was pensioned at the time of his decease, should be required to furnish further evidence of the husband’s service, nor any evidence, in the possession of the Government itself— A similar proposition had been yesterday ruled by the Chairman Out of Order—it was now modified, so that the Chairman pronounced it in order— Reuben Chapman of Alabama, appealed from this decision—and after further Debate, the question on the Appeal, was taken, the vote upon it by Tellers, 63 to 5—no quorum. Seaborn Jones of Georgia moved a Call of the House. A motion for adjournment was taken by yeas and nays 34. to 132—a Quorum and business was recommenced but soon failed for want of a Quorum again. More Debate ensued— Call of the House agreed upon, Doors were closed before the proper time, and then opened again till a Resolution was adopted to take the Question. At three o’clock this day—and accordingly, at three o’clock the voting on the Amendment commenced, and after much waste of time, the Bill was reported to the House; the previous Question was called and without deciding it the House adjourned—

I attended the meeting of the select Committee, upon the Smithsonian
Bequest: all the members present— Owen, Adams, Jenkins, Simms, Davis, Marsh, Wilmot— Mr. Owen’s Bill was further discussed. The Question was taken, upon my Motion to strike out the provision for the appointment of Professors of Agriculture and Horticulture and for the establishment of Teachers for normal schools, both of which however, were carried, by a vote, of five to two— There was in the Bill, an appropriation of five-thousand dollars a year, for the formation of Library— I moved to strike out, in this section the word five, and insert twenty— Believing this, better adapted, to promote and increase the Diffusion of knowledge among Men, than the waste of the Funds, to pay the expenses, of Schools for Children— A Duty, which I believe incumbent, upon the American People themselves, who will be disgraced by recurring to a Foreigner, for charges which they ought to support themselves— My Motion was however, rejected and the Committee, were prepared to report the Bill, as the majority of them have shaped it— A Question was however reserved for the next meeting on Friday next— We found the House in Session.— A report from the Clerk of the House, was received in answer to an inquiry yesterday made, for the cause of the delay in the distribution of the ten thousand, extra-copies of Capt Fremonts Report, The answer is, that all the Copies received by the Clerk had been distributed. Among the Bills, this Day reported, was one by J. W. Lawrence of New York from the Committee on Commerce, for the relief of Joseph Holmes, and others, owners of the Schooner, Industry— This Bill, is founded on a Petition, presented by me, several years since, and will demand special attention from me, to carry it through— Thomas Smith, of Indiana, presented resolutions from the Legislature of that state, approving the course of the President, in relation to the Oregon Territory. Laid on The Table and ordered to be printed—on the motion of John. R. J. Daniel of North Carolina, the House went into Committee of the whole, Joseph R. Ingersoll, in the Chair, on Private Bills and Business. Two Bills, were reported to the House, and passed— Two others, one for the relief of the Heirs of Capt Presley Thornton, and one for the relief of Elizabeth Jones, and other children, if any, of John Kerr; were reported, with recommendation that they should not pass and were rejected— The case of Capt Thornton, was one of those, which had been recommended to me, by Mr.
John Talliaferro, former Member from Virginia— The Claim, was, of the Heirs of Capt Thornton, to Commutation Pay for Military service, to the end of the Revolutionary War— I supported it—to the best of my ability, but without success— It was deemed, to be difficient, in evidence, of service, to the end of the War— soon after three o’clock, the House adjourned— On the day after the passage of the Resolution, for giving notice, on the Oregon Convention, Charles. J. Ingersoll, came to my seat, and had some conversation with me, respecting an Amendment, which I had proposed to him, to insert in the resolution, and which he had promised to move, but had not the opportunity so to do— After he left my seat, W. P. Thomasson of Kentucky, with a smile said to me, that another Member of the House on remarking, the conversation of Mr. Ingersoll with me, had observed, that it was the meeting of Pilate and Herod— I said that this was not very complimentary, but that if it was intended as a censure upon me, for inconsistency, I would answer as Cicero had done before me, upon his reconcilliation after the death of Caesar, with some of the Loco-foco tribunes with whom he had long been in violent opposition and hostility, that I would wish my enemies to be transient, and my friendships to be eternal— Thomasson was much amused at this answer and circulated it freely in whispers, around the House—

I called this morning, at the Bank of the Metropolis, where it was balanced, leaving 33.30. to my credit— Then at Plumbe’s Daguerreotype Office where they took two likenesses of me a full front face, and a profile; both quite successful— At the House Alexander H. Stephens of Georgia, and Robert Dale Owen, of Indiana, presented Resolutions, of those States, respectively— Robert Smith, of Illinois, asked leave to present a Resolution, directing the Committee of Foreign Affairs, to inquire into the expediency, of reporting a Joint Resolution, directing the President of the United States to negotiate with Spain, for the purchase of the Island of Cuba, upon principles, recommended in the proceedings, of a Public Meeting, of the Citizens of Springfield, Illinois— But objection was made, and the Resolution not received— David Levy alias Yulee now a Senator, from the State of Florida; had
already offered, a similar resolution; for the purchase of the Island of Cuba, In the Senate, which he afterwards withdrew These are mere explosive effusions of the Spirit of aggrandizement, which has taken possession, of this People—and which will hereafter characterize their History— The North American Continent, and the Archipeligo of Islands, separating them from the southern Island must and will, in no great distance of time, form component parts, of this great Confederated, Anglo Saxon Republic. The House then proceeded, to the consideration of Private Bills, several of which were passed. In Committee of the Whole Garrett Davis of Kentucky, in the Chair, and others reported to the House, with recommendation that they should not pass, which were accordingly rejected by the House— Those reported favorably by the Committee, were passed by the House, except that for the relief of John Anderson, of Missouri, during the Debate upon which, on the third reading, the House adjourned without taking the Question— While the House were in Session, I gave a sitting, in the Room of the Committee, of Territories, to Mr. Billings, the Painter from Erie, Pennsylvania, for my Portrait. It was the second sitting of about an hour, and he required only one more— We had evening visits from Mr. Healey and Mr. Dubourjal who has painted a beautiful miniature of Mrs. Polk, wife of the President— The competitors for the fourth Painting in the Rotunda, are so numerous that I fear that Mr. Healey will be disappointed, in his desire to obtain it.

At the Unitarian Church I heard, the Revd. Dr. Orvil Dewey of New-York, morning and evening— His morning Sermon was from Hebrews. 9.27—part of the verse—[“]It is appointed unto men once to die” It was a Discourse upon death— A subject, always deeply affecting, but at this time, to me, more than usual— The Sermon however, took a view of death, rather philosophical, than sensitive. Dr. Dewey, maintained that death, was not to be considered in a scriptural sense, as a penalty—that the words . . .
in the text are it is “appointed unto men once to die” which he said did not apply, a penalty—but he omitted the remaining words of the text “But after this the Judgment” which seemed to imply a penalty, or certainly, a heavy responsibility— He said there were three periods, incidental, to the life, of Man, in the Christian dispensation, Baptism, Marriage, and Burial, neither of which necessarily imputed punishment— I did not entirely comprehend, the drift of his Argument, but so far as I did, it seemed to lean, towards the Universalist Creed, without explicitly avowing it— Isaac Hull Adams, dined with us.— After dinner at Saint Johns Church, Mr. Pyne, read the evening service for Sextuagesima Sunday, and preached, from 2 Corinthians, 5.4—“For we, that are in this Tabernacle, do groan, being burdened”—part of the verse— A general Discourse, rather gloomy in its character, upon the numerous burdens, of human Life— In the evening, at seven o’clock, Dr. Dewey, preached again, from the closing part of Revelation 2.10. “Be then faithful, unto death and I will give thee, a Crown of Life”— A text from which, about forty years ago, I heard a funeral Discourse, by President Joseph Willard of Harvard University, upon the death of Revd. Dr. Howard of Boston. Dr. Dewey did not treat it however, as a funeral Discourse— He commenced by some general reflections, upon the natural and universal desire, of Men, for distinction, and observed, that according to the common ideas of mankind, a Crown, was the most exalted emblem of distinction, that could be bestowed; and he maintained, that the pursuit of distinction, was very generally attempted, by the description; of glorious deeds, but that it could only be deserved, by the practise, of virtue, which was in the power of Men of all degrees and conditions—that it was a common and very erroneous idea, that eminent virtue, could only be obtained and manifested, by persons, in eminent station, of wealth, or power. But that virtue of the purest character, and deserving of the brightest Crown, was within the capacity, of every human being, in whatever condition of Life, they may be placed; and he said he had known, an instance of a man in the humblest condition of Human Society, whose life, had been distinguished, as a pattern, of the most exemplary virtue, which consisted, not
merely, in admiring, and extolling but in performing, virtuous deeds— This is excellent, but not very profound morality— It is remarkable, that in the English Bible, the word virtue, is not to be found— Wisdom, righteousness, and Obedience, to the Will of God, are the words used in scripture to signify, what in the Roman language, was called virtue— Dr. Dewey’s evening Discourse, interested, and affected me, more deeply, than that of the morning— The House full, both morning and evening.

The Revd. Mr. Matthew Hale Smith who is now settled as Pastor, of the 2nd. Presbyterian Church, in the place of Mr. Knox, called on me yesterday at the request, of the members of that Church, inviting me to attend, as their Delegate at a Convention, for promoting the observance of the Sabbath, to be held on Tuesday the 24 of this month, at seven o’clock in the evening—at the Presbyterian Church in 4 1/2 street, in this City— With some reluctance, I promised if the state of my health, should permit to attend— This morning I went out to the House of Mr. W. J. Stone, near the Columbian College and Meridian Hill, and sat, for him to take, an outline of my head, by an instrument, of measurement, of his invention, for him, to mould a Bust of me, at his own request— I met there Miss Maria Bache, of whom he had taken a Bust, and a very good likeness— He introduced me also, to Mrs. Elizabeth Stone, his wife— He is an English man, by Birth, and came to this Country; nearly thirty years ago— He is an Engraver by profession, and I employed him, among many other things, to engrave a perfect fac-simile, of the original Declaration of Independence, engrossed on parchment, and signed by members of the Revolutionary Congress, on the 2nd. of August, 1776. The Declaration of the 4. July of that year exists only on paper, and signed only by John Hancock President and Charles Thompson Secretary See the Secret Journals, of that Congress— From Mr. Stone’s House I went to the Capitol—and attended a Meeting of the House of Representatives— It was the day, devoted
to the reception of Resolutions, of Motions of Notice for the introduction of Bills, and of the introduction of Bills, of which previous notice, had been given.— Moses Norris of New-Hampshire, moved an instruction, to the Committee on Post Offices, and Post Roads, to inquire into the expediency, of restoring to Deputy Postmasters, the franking privilege, heretofore allowed them— Daniel. P. King offered a Resolution referring to the Committee, on Foreign Affairs, the Message, and accompanying papers of President Tyler, of 21st. December 1842, concerning our claims in Hayti, with instructions to consider the expediency of obtaining, payment, of them— Henry Y. Cranston of Rhode Island, presented resolutions of the Legislature of that state, in favor of the Tariff of 1842, and against, increasing the rates, of Postage— W. W. Campbell of New York, moved an instruction, to the Committee on Post Offices and Post roads, to inquire, whether deputy postmasters, should not be elected, by the people of their respective Towns, and not removable, except for cause— George Rathbun, of New York, moved a Resolution, for extending, the Revolutionary Pension Act, to the widows of all Revolutionary Officers and Soldiers— Cornelius Darragh, of Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh, moved a similar Resolution, in favor of the Widows, of the Officers and Soldiers, of the War of 1812. A multitude of other Resolutions, upon all sorts of subjects— The usual budget of crudities, not worthy of Notice, were presented, and adopted, or referred over for Debate— But one of them, offered by James. A. Black of South Carolina, was for the appointment, of a Select Committee of nine, to reduce the expenses of the War Department, and the pay of the Army, with power to send for persons and papers, and to report by Bill or otherwise; and one by Isaac. E. Holmes, also of South Carolina, that the Committee on Naval Affairs inquire into the expediency of restoring the Navy Pension Fund— Garrett Davis of Kentucky, moved a resolution to print for the use of the House, the project of a Bill, for a new Tariff, submitted, by the Secretary of the Treasury, to the Committee Ways and Means, and that said Committee, be instructed to furnish the Clerk of the House, with a copy of the same, to be printed— Davis moved, the previous Question and George Rathbun moved to lay the Resolution, on the Table, which was carried by yeas and nays 103. to 69— John W. Tibbatts, of Kentucky, moved to make the river and Harbour Bill, the special order, for next Monday— George. S. Houston of Alabama, moved,
call of the House— Moses Norris, of New Hampshire, moved to lay the Resolution, on the Table; rejected by yeas and nays 63 to 100— The Resolution itself, was lost 108. to 64., not two-thirds— George. W. Jones, of Tennessee, offered a resolution, instructing the Committee, in the District of Columbia, to inquire into the expediency of ceding to the State of Virginia, the County of Alexandria, and to the State of Maryland the County of Washington— Isaac Parish of Ohio, moved a call of the President, for information, relating to the interference, of Great Britain, and France, in the Argentine confederacy, which was laid over for Debate— Schenck and Vantz moved Resolutions, for printing, the Tariff Bill of the Secretary of the Treasury, now before the Committee of Ways and means, and both their resolutions, were laid over for Debate— Numerous Bills were introduced, upon notice given, and numerous notices, of future Bills— Jacob Thompson of Mississippi, moved a resolution, that the Reporters, should be supplied with copies of the Documents, upon which some Debate arose, and without taking the Question, the House adjourned— Revd. Mr. Smith, of the Presbyterian Church in ninth street, and the Revd. Mr. Osburn of Philadelphia, were here this morning, and again this evening— Mr Osburn’s application was for a contribution of money; and for me to deliver a Lecture, upon a project, for raising Funds, for promoting a larger attendance of the People of Philadelphia, to places of Religious worship—which I declined, and informed Mr. Osburn, that I had already done so in answer to former applications, which I had received in the last Autumn, before I left home, to come on to Congress—

I drew upon the Bank of the Metropolis, a check of thirty-three dollars and thirty cents, being the balance, in my favor there, and I received a check from the Speaker of the House, for three hundred dollars— At the House, the Committees were called for Reports on the motion of Thomas B. King. A Bill, introduced yesterday, by E. D. Culver of New York, and then referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, was this day taken from that Committee, and referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs— Its object is, to increase the naval force of the United States— After sundry Reports, from the Committees
on Invalid and Revoluntary Pension Claims, all but two adverse to the Claims.— The Rules were suspended, and the States and Territories called for resolutions; the unfinished business, of yesterday— The Resolution for supplying the Reporters, with Documents, was carried by yeas and nays, 113. to 53. Orlando. B. Ficklin of Illinois, moved that the Bill, making appropriations, for extending the Cumberland Road, through the States of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois, be made the special order, for the first Monday in March; laid over for Debate, as was, the Resolution offered by Robert Smith of Illinois, instructing the Committee of Foreign Affairs, to inquire into the expediency, of purchasing the Island of Cuba— A Message was received from the President, with a Report from the Attorney General, relating to a Contract of Littell, and Brown, for the publication of an edition of Laws of the United States— Referred, to the Committee of Ways and Means— The Pension Appropriation Bill, was resumed— The Amendments reported from the Committee, of the whole, were adopted, and an Amendment offered by John W. Tibbatts, of Kentucky to extend the provisions of the Bill, in favor of Widows, married before the first of January 1800, instead of 1794—was excluded by the Speaker, as not in order— The Bill was then passed— The Indian Appropriation Bill, was then taken up, and partly debated— Hugh. A. Haralson of Georgia, gave notice, that he would call up tomorrow, the Bill reported by the Military Committee, for raising two additional Regiments of Riflemen, and the House, at half past three, adjourned.— There was a Dinner, this day, at Coleman’s Hotel, given by the American Officers, of those of Great Britain, employed on the Survey of the North Eastern Boundary, to which, I had received an invitation, as a guest, but declined, on account of family affliction— Isaac Hull Adams had been here yesterday, in great trouble about arranging, the seats, of the Company, at this Dinner, according to the rules of Etiquette—which we found it impossible, to settle satisfactorily, and so the seats, were taken at haphazard, but without giving, mortal offence— There was an evening Party and Ball, at Mr. Seatons, the Mayor of the City, which we also declined to attend.

I gave yesterday, the last sitting for my Portrait, to Mr. Billings, the painter from Erie Pennsylvania He is himself, well satisfied with it, as a likeness— I called
this morning at the Bank of the Metropolis, and deposited the order for three hundred dollars, which I had received yesterday, from the Speaker of the House— At the House, the Select Committee, appointed on Monday, to retrench expenses, in the War Department, in the pay of the Army, was announced, consisting, of James. A. Black, of South Carolina, Alvan Cullom of Tennessee, Joseph J. McDowell of Ohio, D. M. Barringer of North Carolina, Orvil Hungerford of New York, Caleb. B. Smith, of Indiana, Hugh White of New York, Jefferson. Davis of Missouri, and James. A. Seddon. of Virginia, not one member from New England, on the Committee— It is an anti-Oregon movement, from South Carolina, presented by James A. Black, the only member from that state, who voted for giving the notice— Martin Grover, of New York, moved to reconsider, the vote of yesterday, for supplying the Reporters with Documents, which was carried.— and a Resolution substituted in its place, calling on the Clerk, to report upon the cost, and other consequences, of such a Resolution— Hannibal. Hamlin, moved a resolution, to allow the use of the Hall, for the Congressional Temperance Society, on Thursday evening the 26th. inst. Lost, by yeas and nays. 86. to 62, not two thirds— On motion of Charles. J. Ingersoll, the Committee on Foreign Affairs, was discharged from the consideration of the case of George Brown, late Commissioner to the Sandwich Islands; also from the petition of Citizens of New Jersey, praying Congress, to recognise, and guaranty, the independence, of the Colony of Liberia, in Africa— The petitions were laid on the Table. James Thompson, of Pennsylvania, from the Committee on The Territories, reported back with Amendments, the Bill, to protect the rights, of American Settlers in Oregon, referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union.— John P. Martin of Kentucky, from the Committee on Mileage, reported a Bill, to regulate the pay and milage of members of Congress; referred after some debate to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, by yeas and nays 88. to 71. A motion by Henry of Indiana to make it the special order, for some particular day was ruled out by the Speaker as not in Order— The Indian Appropriation Bill, was then taken up, and much debated, On various points, without coming to a conclusion— The Committee rose, and the House adjourned at four o’clock—

Dr. John Baldwin, one of the largest claimants for the Mexican indemnities, was here this morning— A message from the President, upon this subject, was received at the House yesterday, and laid before it by the Speaker this day, and was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— The subject is full, of iniquitous mystery.— Two instalments of the Indemnity, stipulated by the Mexican Government, were paid, to an Agent, of the American Government, named Voss—and receipted for, by him. And have never been received, by the Government here, nor has any satisfactory account, been given, how the money, has disappeared— Dr. Baldwin, told me, that an Executive Document, of the last Congress, No 144. contains, a Report upon the subject, disclosing, some extraordinary facts, relating to it— But he explicitly charged, Waddy Thompson, then Envoy Extraordinary, and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States, in Mexico, with having, in Concert, with the Agent Voss embezzled the money, and divided it between them— I told Dr. Baldwin, that I could hardly hear, and still less credit, such a statement, that if there was any foundation for it, I considered it incumbent; upon the Administration, of this Government itself, to investigate it, to the bottom, and if not to recover the money, at least to expose, and if possible, to punish the delinquents— I am afraid that I can apologise, to my conscience, for failing, in the performance, of my own duties on this subject, only, by the prostration of my strength, and the disability, of decaying age— As I was entering my carriage, to go to the House, I met at the door, Mr. Heman Lincoln, with a missionary by the name of—and a young Chinees Man, with whom, I had not time for an interview— At the House, on motion of Archibald Atkinson of Virginia, the Committee of Naval Affairs, was instructed to inquire into the expediency, of having completed, and fitted for service, the ship of the Line, New-York, and the Frigate St. Lawrence, now in the stocks, at Gosport, in Virginia— James. C. Dobbin of North Carolina, from the Committee of Elections, reported in favor of John Runk—as a Member of the House from New Jersey, against the memorial, of Isaac. G. Farlee, concluding with the Resolution, that Runk, is entitled to his Seat. Lucien. B. Chase of Tennessee, made a minority report, from the same Committee, against Runk—and in favor of Farlee, both the Reports, were laid on the Table, and ordered to be printed— John. P. Martin of Kentucky, from the Committee, on Milage, reported a Bill, prohibiting the allowance of travelling Fees, for any Senator, for attendance, at any called Executive Session of the Senate, unless, for actual travel— This Bill, roused a sharp debate and the House, manifested, a large majority, for driving it through at once, but the morning hour expired.— and the House went into Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union upon the Indian, Appropriation Bill, John. R. J. Daniell
in the Chair— Amendments were moved, by Hugh White of New York, and Martin delegate from Wisconsin, which were reported to the House, and one by Thomasson of Kentucky, against the Choctaw Academy, which was rejected; and the Bill was passed by yeas and nays 150. to 10—of which last number, I was one— Dr. John M. Thomas, was here this evening, and prescribed, for a new complaint, of inflamatory symptoms, in my Legs—

I attended this morning, a meeting of the Select Committee, on the Smithsonian Bequest— Present, Owen, Chairman, Adams, Simms, and Jenkins. There was some farther discussion, upon the Amendments proposed to the Bill, and without coming to a conclusion. The Committee, adjourned, to meet again next Friday, with a view then, to direct the Chairman, to report the Bill, as amended— I said I should not object to this, but should not hold myself bound, to support it in the House— Mr. Simms said, that his objection to it, as unConstitutional, remained, in full force, in his mind— In the House, the Bill, for curtailing the milage pay, of Senators, was resumed— A motion for the Previous Question was pending, on which there was no Quorum voting. Haralson of Georgia, moved a Call of the House, which was commenced, had a large Quorum answering to their names, was superceded— An Amendment moved yesterday, by Jacob Thompson of Mississippi, was rejected and the Bill was passed by Yeas and nays—141. to 10.— I voted against it, believing that it will sleep, in the Senate, or be returned to the House, with an Amendment, touching, the constructive pay of the Members of the House, which will be sure to demolish the Bill— It is the constant practise, of many members of the House, to absent themselves, without leave, for days, weeks, and sometimes months, and yet receiving pay, as if they attended regularly every day of the Session, and this is the Body of economists, so severely prohibiting that constructive pay, to members of the Senate. Haralson moved to go into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, to consider Bills, reported, by the military Committee, but Thomas. J. Henley, moved to go into Committee of the whole, to take up Bills, on the private Calendar— The House decided against the motion of Haralson, and in favour of that of Henley— A Debate followed, upon one private Bill for the relief of John Anderson. At its third reading the Question was taken by Tellers, 32. to 69—no
Quorum— Hannibal. Hamlin of Maine, moved to lay it on the Table, which was carried by yeas and nays. 99. to 50—and the House adjourned. The Steamer, Cambria, arrived from Liverpool and Halifax, at Boston, on Wednesday evening, at 1/2 past ten o’clock. She sailed from Liverpool on the fourth instant, and brings, Dispafrom Louis McLane, our Minister at London, to the Secretary of State, and from the British Government, to Mr. Pakenham, and a Count. M. De Banlieu, as a successor to Mr. Serruys, from Belgium— It brings also—Queen Victoria’s speech, at the opening of Parliament, on the 22d. of January— A total Revolution, is announced, in the Commercial policy of Great Britain— The Ministry of Sir Robert Peel, is restored, after their resignation, and an abortive attempt, by Lord John Russell, to form, another Ministry— The Corn Laws, are to be immediately repealed, totally, or gradually, in the course of three years— The complexion, of the intelligence, is altogether, pacific, and concilliatory— Mr. Pakenham’s rejection of the proposition made by Mr. Buchanan—to divide, the Oregon, by the 49. parallel of Latitude, without referring it, to his Government, has been formally disapproved, both by Sir Robert Peel, and Lord John Russell, in the House of Commons— The Report of our Secretary of the Treasury, on the State of the Finances, of the Third of December last, has been highly extolled, for its exposition, of the principles of Free Trade, and ordered to be printed, in the House of Peers, for the use of its Members— A token of approbation without example— It is evident, that the Oregon Question, will be settled by the Repeal of the Corn Laws and the sacrifice of the American Tariff, a bargain, both sides of which will be for the benefit of England, and to our disadvantage— A purchase, of Peace, the value of which, can only be tested by the lapse of time.—

Dr. Laury, Minister of the first Presbyterian Church, in this City, called on me this morning, with an invitation to attend, the Convention, of the Churches in this District, for promoting, the observance of the Sabbath— I had already received a similar invitation, from Mr. Matthew Hale Smith, Minister of the 2d. Presbyterian Church, to attend, as their Delegate— The preliminary meeting, is to be held, next Tuesday evening, at 9 o’clock at the Presbyterian Church, on four and a half Street, which I promised to attend,
if my health, would permit— The meeting of the Committee of Manufactures, had been adjourned, to this morning at eleven o’clock— I attended accordingly, but only two other Members of the Committee, were present— Charles. Hudson of Massachusetts, and James. H— Johnson of New Hampshire— No business could of course be done—and no order could be taken, upon the only subject referred to the Committee— They adjourned, to meet again, next Wednesday. At the House, B. B. French the Clerk was absent, from indisposition— Sundry Reports from Committees, were received—among which, one from Thomas. J. Henley, of Indiana, Chairman of the Committee on Patents— A Bill from the Senate for the relief of Charles. G. Page, an examiner at the Patent Office, a Bill to suspend the operation, of the 2d. 7th. and 15th. Sections of the Patent Act, of 4th. July 1836. which prohibits the granting of Patents, to any person appointed, or employed, in the Patent Office— This suspension, was to exempt Mr. Page, from this prohibition, for allowing him to take out a Patent, for an invention, of his own in the application of electricity, and Magnetism— George W. Hopkins of Virginia, opposed the Bill, and Martin Grover of New York moved to lay it on the Table, which was carried, by yeas and nays 113. to 54— I voted in the affirmative, no sufficient reason being assigned, in my judgment, for an especial exception in this case, from the salutary rule, of the Law. William L. Yancey, of Alabama moved twice, that when the House adjourned it should be till Tuesday, the 24. in honor of the memory of Washington, whose birthday, occurs this year on Sunday, the 22d. and is to be kept, as a festival, on the ensueing day— Yancey failed, in his first attempt, and succeeded in his second— Committee of the whole on private Bills, Samuel F. Vinton, of Ohio in the Chair— Among the Bills was one granting commutation, of half pay, to the Heirs of Col William Grayson—which was earnestly opposed, by Henry S. Clark, of North Carolina, Jacob Collamer, of New York, and Jacob Brinkerhoff, of Ohio— I took part in this discussion, by bearing testimony, to the merit and services, of Col Grayson, to whom in the year 1785. I brought a letter of introduction, from Mr. Jefferson, then Minister of the United States, in France— Mr. Grayson, was then a member of the Confederation, Congress in Session at New York— Richard. Henry Lee
of Virginia, being then President of Congress, in whose house, I passed several weeks, as a Member, of his family and where I frequently met Col Grayson. My testimony, was not, to the special merits of the claim, but to those of him, whose Heirs, are now the Claimants— The Committee rose, without coming, to any decision, and the House adjourned over to Tuesday— Mr. Healey and M. Dubourjal, paid us evening visits—

In the Hall of the House of Representatives, Divine Service, was performed, this morning, by the Revd. Dr. Orvil Dewey, who preached, from 2. Samuel 12.5. “And David’s anger, was greatly kindled, against the man, and he said to Nathan, as the Lord, livith, the man that hath done this thing, shall surely die 6. And he shall restore the Lamb, four fold, because he did this thing, and because he had no pity. 7. And Nathan said to David, Thou, art, the man.”— The Discourse, was a running commentary, of this most memorable story, of David’s transgressions, in relation, tothe Hitiand of all the, admirable lessons of morals, so thickly sown, throughout, the Holy Scriptures, there is none, more awful, and impressive;—none which exhibits, in such burning characters, the frailty, and perversity, of the human heart— Dr. Dewey presented, in glowing characters, the transcendant virtues, and gigantic intellect, of the Man, after God’s own heart, of the Author of the Psalms, inspiration a part, the most sublime, compositions, of piety, virtue, and devotion, that ever emanated, from the mind of Man, contrasted, with the baseness, the meanness, the hypocrisy, the cruelty of this succession of conduct, and exhibiting, the lamentable, infirmities, of the most exalted, of the Human race— It was a saddening and melancholy, and I may hope instructive Lesson— In the afternoon, at Saint John’s Church, Mr. Pyne read the evening service, for the Sunday, before Lent, and preached, from 1. Corinthians, 13.6—“Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth, in the truth” a fragment of a sentence, not even indicating who it is that rejoiceth, but he told us it was Charity—and briefly expounded, that noble description of Charity, so happily characterized in the context of the Chapter— Returning home, from Church, I walked, with Mr. John. A. Dix, now a Member of the Senate, from the State of New-York,
who came in, and sat with me about half an hour, in conversation, on the present state, of our Public Affairs, and the recent news, from Europe— In the evening at the Unitarian Church, I heard Dr. Dewey, again preach from Mark, 16.16. “He that believeth, and is baptised, shall be saved, and he that believeth not, shall be condemned,” So he read the text—the word in which is damned— He said that as this word had become exceptionable in consequence of its abuse sometimes, in profane language, he substituted, the word condemned, which was the meaning of the word in the original— The word baptized also in this text, he said meant, an open profession of Christianity— The Sermon, was a dissertation upon faith and an ingenious argument, to exhibit the reasons, why the Gospel, ascribes, so transcendent a power to belief, for accomplishing the Salvation of Man—
