The birthday of President Washington, is usually celebrated on the 22d. of February— His real birthday having been on the 11th. of February 1733, old style or according to the Julien calendar— The computation of that Calendar is still observed in Russia, and there is now, twelve days of difference, between that and the Gregorian Calendar, according to which, this is the 11th. day of February, at this time— But the change of Calendar having been made, in the British Dominions, by an Act of Parliament, in 1752, after that time, so long as Washington lived, and until the year 1800. the difference between the two Calendars, was only 11. days. By the reform of the Calendar that year 1800, was not a Bisextile, by the Julien Calendar it was, and thus added one day more, to the difference between the two— The practise of keeping Washington’s birthday, as a festival, having commenced, before his death, had fixed it, on the 22d., and has been continued on that day, hitherto, during the present Century, though it should now be kept on the 23d.— This has been affected, for the present year, only because the 22d. came on a Sunday.— The same Chronological rule, applies to my Father’s Birth day, which was the 19. October, 1735. His family and friends, observed it, even after the commencement of the present Century, on the 30th. October—by according to
the reformed Calender, it should be on the 31st. The House of Representatives on Saturday adjourned over this day, in honor to the memory of Washington— The Senate, had adjourned, from last Thursday, to this day, when they merely met, and again adjourned till tomorrow— I spent this morning, with my Grand daughter Louisa, in partly retrieving, the arrears of this Journal—and about three o’clock, walked to the Office of the National Intelligencer, to procure the paper of the day, which had not been left at our house, this morning— We had no interruption of visitors, and beguiled the time in the evening, by reading the European News, brought, by the Steamer Cambria, which arrived at Boston last Wednesday— By the same vessel I received a Speech, in pamphlet of M. Thiers in the French House of Deputies, addressed to me, by Mr. William. R. King, Minister of the United States, in France, at this time— Mr. Dix, the Senator from the State of New-York, had also sent me, the [“]Courrier des Etats-Unis,” of the 6th. July 1845.— which contains a Speech of the French minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Guizot, to the House of Deputies, in June last—explaining, his system of Policy, and the principles, upon which the Government of France and Great Britain, have interfered, in the Affairs of the American Continents, and especially to prevent the annexation of Texas, to this Union— President Polk, in his Message, at the commencement, of the present Session of Congress, complained, of this interference, on the part of France, and boasted, that the measure had been accomplished, in spite of it— M. Guizot’s system, openly avows, that France, has an interest, and a right to hold the balance of power, between the three, Great Powers of the American Hemisphere—the United States, England, and the States of Spanish origin, and he maintains that it is the interest of France to support, an equilibrium between them— To this system of Policy, the People of this Union cannot assent, and M. Thiers in his speech, of 20. January last, assails it, as a total departure from the ancient and undeviating system, pursued as he asserts, towards the United States of America, by France from the period of the American Revolution— That Policy he says, had always been, to favor the aggrandizement of the United States, with referrence to great Britain, and yet to hold a balance between them—that Great Britain, was the natural,
rival, and antagonist, of France, but that there never could be antagonism, of principle, or of Policy, between France and the United States; that it was absurd, and ridiculous, that there ever could be, a hostile Policy, or a rational fear, of the United States, on the part of France, and therefore, that the true policy of France was at all times, to favor the prosperity of the United States, and their aggrandizement in America— He thought therefore, that the President of the United States, had complained, not without reason, of this principle of equilibrium asserted by M. Guizot—“Gentlemen, said he, I acknowledge it to my shame, I have for a very long time, studied the Map of the World, and the interests, crossing each other upon it. Well, I declare to this House, it is the first time in my life, that I ever heard pronounced the words, ‘American equilibrium’— Never, never, to my knowledge, was it pronounced, by any statesman”— The report of the speech says, that this produced a “movement in the Chamber of Deputies”—and well it might— M. Guizot’s equilibrium, should produce a movement, more extensive, than the House of Deputies of France— M. Thiers admits, the European balance, of power, but denies its extension, to the American Hemisphere, and refers, to Mr. Winthrop’s speech, at this Session of Congress, as an evidence, that he, in recommending an Arbitration for the settlement of the Oregon Question with England, did not venture to recommend a European Crowned Head, as the arbitrator, which he M. Thiers attributes, to his disgust, at M. Guizot’s system of equilibrium—
24— V.15.— Shrove Tuesday.

At the House, the reading of the Journal, of Saturday last was dispensed with. A practise of evil tendency, creeping into the House— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine, moved to reconsider the vote, to lay on the Table, the Bill, to grant the Patent, to Dr. Charles. G. Page, an Officer, in the Patent Office— This motion was postponed for future consideration. This was the day for the presentation of Petitions, but the House went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union on yeas and nays 106 to 67. Thomas Smith of Illinois, in the Chair—and took up the River and Harbour Bill— Felix
G. McConnell, after breathing a blast against the Bill itself, moved to lay it aside, and take up another—which Motion, was rejected— The Amount of the Appropriation, is $1,348,450—besides an indefinit Sum, for the purchase, of the Louisville and Portland Canal— McConnell, moved to strike out, the first Section of the Bill, and sputtered a speech, of about 10. minutes, when his Motion was rejected.— Robert. B. Rhett, moved to strike out, all after the enacting clause, and delivered a diatribe, against the whole system of internal improvements, to which, Thomasson of Kentucky replied— Crosier of Tennessee, proposed an Amendment, an appropriation of $250,000. to complete the Canal; round the Muscle Shoals, of the Tennessee River— He complained, that the North Western Members, of the Committee of Commerce, had lavished too much Money, upon the Lakes, and that a grant, made several years ago of four hundred thousand Acres of Land, to the State of Alabama, to dig a Canal, round the Muscle Shoals, had not accomplished the object— Houston and Chapman of Alabama expatiated, upon the faithful application of that grant, but admitted to be sure, that it had not accomplished its purpose, but McConnell charged the State, with gross mis-management, and waste of that Fund— Schenck of Ohio, made an hour speech, in favor of the Bill, animadverting to the composition of the Committee of Commerce, and defending them, against the censure of Crosier— He complained also, that the Annual Message of the President, had totally omitted all recommendation, not only of Public improvement, but even of Harbour defences.— The Committee rose, and the Speaker communicated to the House, reports, from the Post Office, Navy, and Patent Office Departments: The Report from the Commissioner of Patents, was ordered to be printed; referred to the Committee on Patents. It comes this year from Edmund Burke, late a member of Congress from New Hampshire, appointed in the place of Henry L. Ellsworth, removed, for extraordinary service in the Department. The House adjourned soon after three— In the evening at 7. o’clock, I attended at the Convention, for the observance of the Sabbath,—In the vestry of the 1st. Presbyterian Church in 4 1/2 street— Of which the Revd. Mr. Sprole, is the Minister— My neighbour Albion. K. Parris, went with me.— There were nearly
two hundred persons present— Delegates, from the Presbyterian, Methodist, Baptist, and Episcopalian Churches, in the District of Columbia, but no Roman Catholics, Quakers, nor Unitarians— Mr, Parris, was chosen Chairman, and the Committee appointed, for organizing the Meeting— They reported a list of Officers, nominating me as President, with several vice-Presidents, and Secretaries, the first of whom was Matthew St. Clair Clarke. A business Committee was appointed, who retired and Reported, rules for the proceedings, and fifteen Resolutions, for discussion— They were immediately debated, and with some Amendments adopted, and agreed to be reported, to an adjourned Meeting of the Convention, in the Church at 10. o’clock tomorrow morning— It was past 10. o’clock, when with Mr. Parris, I returned home.

At ten this morning, I attended again, the Convention, for promoting the observance of the Sabbath, at the first Presbyterian Church, on four and a half street— At the Meeting last evening, a Delegation, from the Congressional Prayer meeting, were invited, to participate, in the proceedings of the Convention, and several of its members, attended this day— There has been it seems, for several years, an Association of Members of Congress, who hold occasional meetings, for uniting in Prayer; to which, I have never been invited, and the existence of which, I had not till now known— The Resolutions, reported from the Meeting last evening, were now produced, and adopted, with certain Amendments—but the Convention sat till two o’clock, and when the hour of twelve, the time for Meeting, at the House of Representatives, I was obliged to leave, the Chair of the Convention, and repair to the House— Among the reports of the Committees was one, by Robert M. T. Hunter, Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, of a Bill to retrocede, the County of Alexandria, to the State of Virginia. Another Bill reported by William. W. Paine of Alabama, from the same Committee, was to repeal an Act requiring one of the Judges of the Circuit Court, of the District of Columbia to reside in Alexandria. This Bill was read three times and passed without opposition. Alexander Ramsay of Pennsylvania, reported from the Committee on Military Affairs, a Bill for the commencement of Fortifications, at New Bedford Mass. Isaac E.
Holmes, Chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs, reported a Bill, to reduce into one Act, the several Acts, concerning Naval Pensions, and to repeal some others. He reported also from the Committee on the Rules, a new one, that upon Bills making Appropriations of money, for internal improvements, a separate vote of the House, may be taken, upon each item separately— Tibbatt’s moved to lay it on the Table, which was rejected, by yeas and nays, 69. to 95—and the Rule was adopted 98. to 75. and finally passed 106. to 71.— A motion to reconsider was rejected 86. to 95. The River and Harbour Appropriation Bill, was taken up in Committee of the Whole, on the state of the Union, Thomas Smith of Indiana in the Chair. W. W. Paine, of Alabama, spoke an hour, against the Bill, generally and specially— Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, spoke in favor of it— Quarter past three the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— At seven o’clock this evening, I attended, at the adjourned Meeting; of the Sabbath Convention, at the first Presbyterian Church, in four and a half street where I presided— The resolutions, reported by the business Committee, were finally acted upon, amended and adopted. The House was crowded with Auditors, whom I addressed in a short speech— Several other addresses were made—a Committee for preparing and publishing, a Report of the proceedings of the Convention was appointed, and between ten and eleven o’clock, the Convention adjourned— Mr. Lawrence a reporter, for the Baltimore Sun newspaper, requested me, to write out my Address, for publication in that paper. Mr. Parris, returned home, with me—

I employed, all the morning till the time, for the meeting of the House, in writing and, with the help of my Grandaughter, the substance of my remarks at the meeting of the Convention last evening—which I gave to Mr. Lawrence, the Reporter for the Baltimore Sun, who called for them, this afternoon— At the House, W. W. Paine, of Alabama, on pretence of making a personal explanation, delivered a second Speech, against the River and Harbour Bill—to which Jacob Brinkerhoff of Ohio, again replied— James. C. Dobbin, of North Carolina, from the Committee of Elections, gave notice, that he would call up to-morrow, the Reports of that Committee, of the contested election, of John Runk from the State of New Jersey— Thomas. F. Vinton, gave notice, that he would move an Amend
ment to the rule adopted yesterday, by extending it, to all Bills for Light Houses, Fortifications and Impost Duties— Laid over for consideration hereafter— Felix. G. McConnell, moved a resolution, that no Member should be allowed to speak, more than ten minutes on any Private Bill, which the Speaker, must be considered, as a notice, being a proposition, to change the rules, which must be laid over, for one day— Communications were received from the War and Navy Departments— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Thomas. Smith of Indiana in the Chair, on the River and Harbour Bill— Supported by Robert McClelland of Michigan, and opposed by Robert. C. Rhett of South Carolina, each for his hour. Charles Hudson of Massachusetts, commenced a Speech, and was soon called to order, first by Shelton. F. Leake, and next by George. W. Hopkins both of Virginia, for irrelevancy— The Speaker declared Hudson both times, to be in order. Hopkins appealed from his decision, which was sustained, 60. to 40. but no quorum voting, whereupon the Committee rose, Tibbatts moved a call of the House, but they preferred to adjourn, which they did—

At ten o’clock this morning, I attended a Meeting of the Select Committee on the Smithsonian Bequest, present Owen, Chairman, Adams, Simms, Jenkins, Marsh, and Jefferson Davis—absent Wilmot.— The Chairman, conformably to the order, adopted at the last meeting had prepared a Report, to be submitted with the Bill, to the House— It contained a statement, of the embezzlement of the Fund, by investing it in the stocks of the states of Arkansas, Illinois, and Michigan— I had moved, to have this statement made and provided for in the Bill—but excepting Mr. Marsh, no other member of the Committee, would consent to it. They were unwilling to uncover the nakedness of the States— They consented however with reluctance, to have it made in the report, which Mr. Owen had rather awkwardly done, with an expression of the opinion of the Committee, that there would be, no ultimate loss, to the United States, of the Funds thus invested— I moved to strike out of the Report, this expression of confidence, which I could not honestly avow— It was accordingly struck out—leaving a bare statement of the Facts, to be made— The Chair
man, was directed, in presenting the Report, and Bill, to move that they should be printed, and made the special order of the Day, for the second Tuesday, in April— The Committees upon this subject, of the House, have heretofore, been unanimous, in the Reports— All which have been made by me— But the House, has never been prevailed upon, to take them into consideration— In this Committee, no two members, excepting Mr. March, and myself, have agreed in opinion, with regard to the future management of the Fund— I doubt, if there will be more harmony in the House, for never was there, a benevolent and charitable purpose, more unfortunately endowed, than that of James Smithson, intrusted, to the good faith, and intelligence, of the North American Congress—

In the House, John S. Chipman of Michigan, a member of the Committee of Elections, moved to take up their Reports, upon the New Jersey contested election— The House preferred to go, into Committee of the whole, on Private Bills, by virtue of the rule that on the first and fourth Friday, of each month, this being the fourth, the calendar of Private Bills, shall be called over, and those to the passage of which no objection is made, shall be first considered, and disposed of— Thirteen Bills were thus reported to the House, and passed; and a Bill granting a Pension, to Orris Crosby, was objected to, by Simms, of South Carolina— Whereupon Wentworth of Illinois, if his objection should be persisted in, he would object, to every other Bill which should be called up— Which he accordingly did, till a debate arose, which finally compelled the Committee to rise— Hannibal Hamlin, moved to go into Committee again—but without success— Stephen Douglass of Illinois, Chairman of the Committee on Territories, moved to go into Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union, upon the Oregon Territorial Bill— Which motion also failed— After the receipt of several Communications from the Executive Departments, Cobb of Georgia, moved to go again into Committee of the Whole on private Bills, but on taking the Question, there was no Quorum, voting, and the House adjourned— Mr. John. A. Rockwell, of Connecticut and his brother, an inhabitant of Norwich, passed part of the evening here—

A Snow storm began last night, and continued, and violent all this day— At the House, Alexander. D.
Simms, of the fourth Congressional District of South Carolina, in the form of a personal explanation, assigned his reasons, for objecting yesterday, against the passage of the Bill, for the relief of Orris. Crosby, which arrested the progress of the Committee of the whole, in clearing out the Private Calendar— John Wentworth of Illinois, who had yesterday, objected to every Bill, after that in favor of Crosby, and thereby, broken up the Committee of the Whole, made a counter explanation and an Argument for the Bill, in favor of Crosby. But there was no Question, before the House, and the two personal explanations ended in smoke— Edmund. W. Hubard presented resolutions, from the Legislature of Virginia, requiring of Congress, to provide by law, for the satisfaction, of all Virginia Military Land warrants for Revolutionary service, now unsatisfied. Referred to the Committee on Public Lands—numerous Reports were received from the Committees— Alexander Harper of Ohio, presented resolutions of the Legislature of that state, against any increase, of the rights of postage— Referred to the Committee on Post Offices, and Post Roads— Robert. Dale. Owen, Chairman of the Select Committee, on the Smithsonian Bequest, presented a Report and Bill, as a substitute of that, which he had introduced; and moved, that the Report be printed— That the substitute be referred to the Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union, and printed separately, in the form of a Rule, and be made a special order of the day of the second Tuesday, in April next— A division of the Question was called, upon which Mr. Owen. urged the propriety, and necessity, for the credit of the Country to make it a special Order, for a not distant day— The Resolution was carried, by a vote of more than two thirds—and the specific assignment, for discussing the Bill, was made. The House then went into Committee of the whole, on Private Business— Rathbun of New York in the Chair— The Bill, granting commutation, of half pay, to the legal Representatives, of Colonel William Grayson, of the Revolutionary Army, was again debated. Speeches in its favor, were made by James. A. Seddon, Thomas H Bayly, Joseph Johnson of Virginia, and Garrett Davis of Kentucky and against it, by Henry. S. Clarke, of North Carolina— Samuel Gordon of New York moved to lay the Bill aside, to be reported to the
House, with a recommendation that it do not pass— I moved to strike out those words, but the Chairman thought, it was sufficient, to strike out the word not— The Question was taken by Tellers, and carried 64 to 60— The Bill was reported accordingly, and the House adjourned without taking the Question upon it— I rode to and from the Capitol on account of the snow—
